class_notes:
(Freshmen Seminar - Limited to First Year Students Only) - You must have permission to enroll in-person.


This class will be taught entirely in-person and will meet two days per week.


Why do individuals sometimes cooperate, act in the group's best interests, even when doing so is contrary to their short-term self-interest? When do efforts to promote such cooperation succeed or, instead, end in spirals of retaliatory conflict or inter-group violence? We explore these questions in many social settings, e.g., 'altruistic' behavior in various animal species; the willingness of soldiers to risk their lives in battle; participation in civil rights action or violent rebellion; conflict among ethnic groups; the varying success of community development and labor movements; and more. We also examine diversity and cooperation in a democracy: why diversity might be valuable for a group, how to promote successful dialogue among diverse groups, how inequality and the information age affect the prospects for cooperation under diversity. We look at a variety of applied explanations, including the role of reciprocity and retaliation; asymmetries in power; social and political institutions; norms, ideas, identity, and culture; social psychological dynamics; and genetics and natural selection.
